newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU law ruling hits Swedish ban on TV child adverts.
newsitem.headline: EU law ruling hits Swedish ban on TV child adverts.

text.p: A legal adviser at the European Court of Justice has told Sweden, which bans TV advertising aimed at children, that it cannot restrict commercials broadcast from another European Union member state.

Advocate-General Murray Jacobs issued an opinion on Tuesday saying the EU's Television without Frontiers directive "prevents a member state from taking action against television advertisements broadcast from another member state".

However, Jacobs said EU law allowed Sweden to ban such commercials if both the advertiser and the broadcaster were based there and they were broadcast on a domestic TV channel received only by viewers in the country.
Opinions by the Advocates-General are only advisory, but are often followed by the court in later rulings.
A ruling against Sweden could prevent it from intervening against advertisements broadcast from other EU countries.
Europe's advertising industry sees the case as a critical test of its right to provide services across the EU.
Swedish Consumer Ombudsman Axel Edling, fearing the Swedish ban may be undermined, reacted with disappointment.
"Consumer protection in Sweden takes several steps backwards if this will also be the final judgement," Edling told the Swedish news agency TT in Stockholm.
Such a ruling may affect not only advertising aimed at children. "It would also prevent us from intervening against misleading, unethical or inappropriate advertisement," he said.
Sweden argues that children cannot always differ between advertisements and TV programmes.
It is the only EU country that has a general ban on advertising aimed at children under 12.
The Luxembourg-based court has been asked to decide whether EU law allows Sweden to bar advertisements aired by a TV channel based in a member state where they are legal.

The case involves an advertisement for a magazine about dinosaurs that publishing firm De Agostini Forlag AB aired on television channels TV3 and TV4 in 1993. TV3 is a British-based channel broadcasting to Sweden while TV4 is based in Sweden.
The Swedish Consumer Ombudsman, saying the advertisement should be banned, decided to take the firm to the Swedish Market Court, which asked for a preliminary ruling from the European Court.
The court battle is a sign of the realities of the new television age with authorities unable to control the contents of programmes broadcast from another country.
